revision.text:
{{for|the musician|Aldo Rossi (musician)}} {{Infobox architect |name = Aldo Rossi |image = Aldo_Rossi_1986-87.jpg |image_size = A4 |caption = (ca. 1986-87) |nationality = Italian |birth_date = {{birth date|1931|5|3|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Milan]], Italy |death_date = {{death date and age|1997|9|4|1931|5|3|df=y}} |death_place = Milan, Italy |alma_mater = [[Polytechnic University of Milan]] |significant_buildings= [[Monte Amiata Housing|Monte Amiata complex]], [[Teatro Carlo Felice]], [[Teatro La Fenice]], [[Bonnefanten Museum]] |awards = [[Pritzker Prize]] (1990) }} '''Aldo Rossi''' (3 May 1931 – 4 September 1997) was an Italian [[architect]] and [[designer]] who achieved international recognition in four distinct areas: architectural theory, drawing and design and also product design.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Germano |last=Celant |lastauthoramp=yes |first2=Diane |last2=Ghirardo |title=Aldo Rossi: Drawings |publisher=Skira |location=Milan |year=2008 |isbn=978-88-6130-143-6 }}</ref>
He was the first Italian to receive the [[Pritzker Architecture Prize|Pritzker Prize]]<ref>Pritzker Prize for Architecture - [http://www.pritzkerprize.com/about/purpose chriteria]</ref> for architecture.
==Early life==
He was born in [[Milan]], [[Italy]]. After early education by the [[Somaschi Fathers|Somascan Religious Order]] and then at [[:it:Collegio arcivescovile Alessandro Volta|Alessandro Volta College]] in [[Lecco]], in 1949 he went to the school of architecture at the [[Polytechnic University of Milan]]. His thesis advisor was [[:it:Piero Portaluppi|Piero Portaluppi]] and he graduated in 1959.
In 1955 he had started writing for, and from 1959 was one of the editors of, the architectural magazine [[Casabella|Casabella-Continuità]], with editor in chief [[Ernesto Nathan Rogers]]. Rossi left in 1964, when the chief editorship went to Gian Antonio Bernasconi. Rossi went on to work for [[:it:Società (rivista)|Società magazine]] and Il_contemporaneo, making him one of the most active participants in the fervent cultural debate of the time.
His early articles cover architects such as [[Alessandro Antonelli]], [[:it:Mario Ridolfi|Mario Ridolfi]], [[Auguste Perret]] and [[Emil Kaufmann]] and much of this material became part of his second book, ''Scritti scelti sull'architettura e la città 1956-1972'' (''Selected writings on architecture and the city from 1956 to 1972''). He married the Swiss actress Sonia Gessner, who introduced him to the world of film and theater. Culture and his family became central to his life. His son Fausto was active in movie-making both in front of and behind the camera and his daughter Vera was involved with theatre.
==Career==
He began his professional career at the studio of [[Ignazio Gardella]] in 1956, moving on to the studio of [[Marco Zanuso]]. In 1963 also he began teaching, firstly as an assistant to [[:it:Ludovico Quaroni|Ludovico Quaroni]] (1963) at the school of urban planning in [[Arezzo]], then to [[Carlo Aymonino]] at the [[Università Iuav di Venezia|Institute of Architecture in Venice]]. In 1965 he was appointed lecturer at the [[Polytechnic University of Milan]] and the following year he published ''The architecture of the city'' which soon became a classic of architectural literature.
His professional career, initially dedicated to architectural theory and small building work took a huge leap forward when [[Carlo Aymonino|Aymonino]] allowed Rossi to design part of the [[Monte Amiata Housing|Monte Amiata complex]] in the [[Gallaratese|Gallaratese quarter]] of Milan. In 1971 he won the design competition for the extension of the San Cataldo Cemetery in [[Modena]], which made him internationally famous.
After suspension from teaching in Italy in those politically troubled times, he moved to [[ETH Zurich]], occupying the chair in architectural design from 1971 to 1975.
In 1973 he was director of the International Architecture Section at the [[:it:XV Triennale di Milano|XV Milan Triennial Exhibition of Decorative Arts and Modern Architecture]], where he presented, among others, his student [[Arduino Cantafora]]. Rossi's design ideas for the exhibition are explained in the International Architecture Catalogue and in a 16mm documentary ''Ornament and crime'' directed by Luigi Durissi and produced along with Gianni Braghieri and Franco Raggi. In 1975, Rossi returned to the teaching profession in Italy, teaching architectural composition in Venice.
In 1979 he was made a member of the prestigious [[Accademia di San Luca|Academy of Saint Luke]]. Meanwhile, there was international interest in his skills. He taught at several universities in the United States, including [[Cooper Union]] in New York City and [[Cornell University]] in Ithaca (New York State). At Cornell he participated in the ''Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies'' joint venture with New York's [[Museum of Modern Art]], travelling to China and Hong Kong and attending conferences in South America.
In 1981 he published his autobiography, ''A scientific autobiography''. In this work the author, "in discrete disorder", brings back memories, objects, places, forms, literature notes, quotes, and insights and tries to "... go over things or impressions, describe, or look for ways to describe." In the same year he won first prize at the international competition for the design of an apartment block on the corner of Kochstraße and Wilhelmstraße in central [[Berlin]].
In 1984 together with [[Ignazio Gardella]] and [[Fabio Reinhart]], he won the competition for the renovation of the [[Teatro Carlo Felice]] in [[Genoa]], which was not fully completed until 1991. In 1985 and 1986 Rossi was director of the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|3rd (respectively 4th) International Architecture Exhibition]] at the [[Venice Biennale]] including further away display spaces such as Villa Farsetti in [[Santa Maria di Sala]].
In 1987 he won two international competitions: one for a site at the [[Parc de la Villette]] in Paris, the other for the [[Deutsches Historisches Museum]] in Berlin, which was never brought to fruition. In 1989 he continued product design work for Unifor (now part of [[:it:Molteni&C|Molteni Furniture]]) and [[Alessi (Italian company)|Alessi]]. His espresso maker ''La Cupola'', designed for Alessi came out in 1988.
In 1990 he was awarded the [[Pritzker Architecture Prize|Pritzker Prize]].<ref name=Goldberger1990>{{cite journal|last1=Goldberger|first1=Paul|title=Aldo Rossi: Sentiment For The Unsentimental|work=New York Times|date=22 April 1990}}</ref> The city of [[Fukuoka]] in Japan honoured him for his work on the hotel complex ''The Palace'' and he won the 1991 Thomas Jefferson Medal in Public Architecture from the [[American Institute of Architects]]. These prestigious awards were followed by exhibitions at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris, the [[Beurs van Berlage]] in Amsterdam, the [[Berlinische Galerie]] in Berlin and the [[Stedelijk Museum voor Actuele Kunst|Museum of Contemporary Art]] in Ghent, Belgium.
In 1996 he became an honorary member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]] and the following year he received their special cultural award in architecture and design. He died in Milan on 4 September 1997, following a car accident. Posthumously he received the ''[[Torre Guinigi]]'' prize for his contribution to urban studies and the ''Seaside Prize'' of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150509102932/http://seasideinstitute.org/what-we-do/ Seaside Institute], Florida, where he had built a detached family home in 1995.
On appeal his proposals won the 1999 competition for the restoration of the [[Teatro La Fenice]], Venice and it reopened in 2004. In 1999 the Faculty of Architecture of the [[University of Bologna]], based in [[Cesena]], was named after him.
==Work==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Stainless steel kettle "Il Conico" (designed by Aldo Rossi).png|thumb|200px|left|Stainless steel kettle ''Il Conico'', 1986]] --> [[File:Aldo Rossi La Cupola Alessi Coffee Maker Austin Calhoon Photograph.jpg|thumb|200px|Aldo Rossi La Cupola Espresso Maker 1988, produced by Alessi]] His earliest works of the 1960s were mostly theoretical and displayed a simultaneous influence of 1920s [[Italian modernism]] (''see [[Giuseppe Terragni]]''), classicist influences of Viennese architect [[Adolf Loos]], and the reflections of the painter [[Giorgio de Chirico]]. A trip to the [[Soviet Union]] to study [[Stalinist architecture]] also left a marked impression.
In his writings Rossi criticized the lack of understanding of the city in current architectural practice. He argued that a city must be studied and valued as something constructed over time; of particular interest are urban artifacts that withstand the passage of time. Rossi held that the city remembers its past (our "collective memory"), and that we use that memory through monuments; that is, monuments give structure to the city. Inspired by the persistence of Europe's ancient cities, Rossi strove to create similar structures immune to obsolescence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Abramson|first=Daniel|year=2012|title=From Obsolescence to Sustainability, Back Again, and Beyond|url=|journal=Design and Culture|volume=4|issue=3|pages=279–298|via=}}</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Aldo Rossi, Modena Cemetery, Model, c.1983.jpg.png|thumb|right|200px|Model of San Cataldo Cemetery, [[Modena]], Italy, 1971-]] --> He became extremely influential in the late 1970s and 1980s as his body of built work expanded and for his theories promoted in his books ''[[The Architecture of the City]]'' (''L'architettura della città'', 1966) and ''A Scientific Autobiography'' (''Autobiografia scientifica'', 1981).The largest of Rossi's projects in terms of scale was the San Cataldo Cemetery, in [[Modena]], Italy, which began in 1971 but is yet to be completed. Rossi referred to it as a "city of the dead".
The distinctive independence of his buildings is reflected in the micro-architectures of the products designed by Rossi.<ref>{{cite book |last=Buerdek |first=Bernhard E. |year=2005 |title=Design: History, theory and practice of product design |url= |location=Basel, Switzerland |publisher=Birkhauser-Publishers for Architecture |isbn=978-3-764-37029-9 |accessdate= }}</ref> In the 1980s Rossi designed stainless steel [[French press|cafetières]] and other products for [[Alessi (company)|Alessi]], [[Pirelli]], and others.
[[File:Bonnefanten2013-04.jpg|thumb|200px|Central staircase [[Bonnefanten Museum]], [[Maastricht]]]]
==Exhibits==
For the [[Venice Biennale]] in 1979 Rossi designed a floating ''Teatro del Mondo''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archidose.blogspot.com/1999/02/teatro-del-mondo.html |title=Teatro del Mondo |date=8 February 1999 |access-date=29 October 2018 |work=A Daily Dose of Architecture |first=John |last=Hill |publisher=[[Blogspot]]}}</ref> that seated 250 people. For the Venice Biennale in 1984, he designed a triumphal arch at the entrance to the exhibition site. In 2006 two [[pylon (architecture)|pylons]] based on an original 1989 design by Aldo Rossi were erected in front of the Bonnefanten Museum in Maastricht by the Delft architectural firm Ufo Architecten.
==Awards==
Aldo Rossi won the prestigious [[Pritzker Prize]] for architecture in 1990. [[Ada Louise Huxtable]], architectural critic and Pritzker juror, has described Rossi as "a poet who happens to be an architect."

revision.text:
{{further|Settlements of the Cucuteni–Trypillia culture}} {{Cucuteni-Trypillian sidebar}} {{main|Cucuteni–Trypillia culture}}
The chalcolithic [[Cucuteni-Trypillian culture|Cucuteni-Trypillia culture]], in Eastern Europe, left behind thousands of [[Human settlement|settlement]] ruins, circa 6000 to 3500 BC, containing a wealth of [[Archaeology|archaeological]] [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] attesting to their [[Archaeological culture|cultural]] and [[Assemblage (archaeology)|technological]] characteristics.<ref name="Mallory">{{cite book |last1= Mallory|first1= James P|title= In search of the Indo-Europeans: language, archaeology and myth |year=1989 |publisher= Thames and Hudson |location= London |isbn=0-500-05052-X |oclc= 246601873}}</ref>
==Construction techniques== {{See also|Neolithic architecture}} The houses of the Cucuteni-Trypillia settlements were constructed in several general ways: * Wattle and daub homes. * Log homes, called ({{lang-ru|italic=yes|площадки}} ''ploshchadki''). * Semi-underground homes called [[Bordei]]. Some Cucuteni-Trypillia homes were two storeys tall, and evidence shows that the members of this culture sometimes decorated the outsides of their homes with many of the same complex red-ochre swirling designs that are to be found on their pottery. Most houses had thatched roofs and wooden floors covered with clay. Archaeologists have identified two types of [[Timber framing|house framing]] found at Cucuteni-Trypillia sites. One type, somewhat resembling the [[Post and lintel|post and beam]] style, used evenly distributed fork-shaped log pillars that were partially sunk vertically into the ground so that the fork was located at the top and supported the roof beams above. The other type of framing used vertical beams measuring {{cvt|15|–|20|cm|in|disp=x|in diameter (|)}}, or greater, which rested on horizontal ground-sill foundational timbers that were in turn fixed in place on top of the soil.
Most of the walls were built in the [[Wattle and daub|wattle-and-daub]] style. The construction of these houses first started by erecting the framework of larger timbers in place [http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/123.ridicare.casa.stadiul.1.poz.2.jpg (photo 1)], which would take the weight of the structure, and then the space between these timbers would be filled in with a "wattle" made of pliable smaller branches and vines woven together to form a thin twiggy [[Latticework|latticed]] net which was then affixed to the sturdy timbers [http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/116.peretele.c.impletitura.orizontala.jpg (photo 2)]. Onto this wattle framework the "daub" would be applied made of mostly dampened clay soil although sometimes mixed with small bits of straw and/or animal dung to help keep its structural integrity ([http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/145.jpg photo 3]). The daub had to be applied with some force against the wattle in order for it to partially push through the twiggy framework, to which it would stick. Sometimes there would only be a single layer of wattle, and at other times two wattle layers would be used; one for the interior and another for the exterior of the wall. Daub was applied on both sides of the wall, inside and out [http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/casa.jpg (photo 4)], creating a finished wall that was usually about {{convert|5|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} thick. Once applied it was smoothed before drying to create an air- and water-tight barrier against the elements [http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/last.jpg (photo 5)]. After the daub was fully dried, it was usually painted with [[Lime plaster|lime]] to prevent infestations of [[Pest (organism)|pests]].(''note: the photographic examples used in this paragraph were taken from the web page "Recreating a Cucuteni dwelling-house", hosted by The Archaeological Park Cucuteni, see "External Links" at bottom of this article'')<ref>{{Cite web|title=Recreating a Cucuteni dwelling-house |publisher=The Archaeological Park Cucuteni |url= http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/ine.html |language=English, Romanian |accessdate=28 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628222111/http://arts.iasi.roedu.net/cucuteni/arheo/casa/ine.html |archivedate=June 28, 2009}}</ref>
Sometimes the walls were made of [[Log home|horizontally laid timbers]] (similar to log homes) that were then covered with clay daub. Some examples have been found where the horizontal timbers were in turn covered with a wattle-and-daub layer. At other times the horizontal timbers would be covered with a layer of primitively finished lumber. There was no standard practice in building walls there during Neolithic times; sometimes, even in the same house, walls would be constructed with horizontal timbers while others would be covered with finished lumber or wattle-and-daub. This type of horizontal log construction found in Cucuteni-Trypillia houses is called {{lang-ru|italic=yes|площадки}} ''ploshchadki'' in Russian.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Darvill |first= Timothy |work= Archaeology Dictionary |title= definition: ploshchadki | publisher= The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Archaeology |year=2003 |url= http://www.answers.com/topic/ploshchadki |format= online system or service |oclc= 425961211 |accessdate=30 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last= Kipfer |first= Barbara Ann |authorlink =Barbara Ann Kipfer<!--http://archaeologywordsmith.com/arch-cv.php--> |work= Archaeology Wordsmith |title= definition: ploshchadki | publisher = Dr. Barbara Ann Kipfer |url= http://archaeologywordsmith.com/lookup.php?terms=ploshchadki |format= online system or service |accessdate=25 April 2014}}</ref>
Cucuteni-Trypillia houses were roofed with [[Sod|live turf]] or [[Thatching|thatched reeds]].<ref name="Cucoș1">{{Cite journal | last = Cucoș | first = Ștefan |title= Faza Cucuteni B în zona subcarpatică a Moldovei | trans-title= Cucuteni B period in the lower Carpathian region of Moldova | journal = Bibliotheca Memoriae antiquitatis (BMA) (Memorial Library antiquities) | volume = 6 | publisher = Muzeul de Istorie Piatra Neamț (Historical Museum Piatra Neamț) | location = Piatra Neamț, Romania | year = 1999 | url = http://www.neamt.ro/cmj/istorie/piatra-neamt/BMA_2.html | language = Romanian | oclc = 223302267}}</ref> The shape of the house was usually rectangular but some were laid out in an "L" shape. Some of the houses were divided into separate rooms while others contained a semi-open functional space, or [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]].<ref name="Sorochin">{{Cite journal | last = Sorochin | first = Victor | title = Așezările cucuteniene tip Soloceni | trans-title= Soloceni type Cucuteni villages |journal= Memoria Antiqvitatis | volume = 23 |pages= 167–202 |publisher= Muzeul de Istorie Piatra Neamț (Historical Museum Piatra Neamț) |location= Piatra Neamț, Romania |year=2004 |oclc = 241363071}}</ref> Many of the Cucuteni-Trypillia houses were two stories high.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Model of a Cucuteni-Trypillian two-storied house |publisher=The Trypillian Museum |url=http://www.trypillia.com/img/museum/arch/photomodel.jpg |accessdate=29 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060726014714/http://www.trypillia.com/img/museum/arch/photomodel.jpg |archivedate=July 26, 2006 }}</ref>
<gallery> File:CucuteniForkPillar.JPG|Detail of a fork pillar holding a roof beam, with wattle-and-daub layers revealed File:CucuteniWallreconstruction.jpg|Wall reconstruction showing a wall with two layers of wattle and daub laid over a timber frame post File:CucuteniFloorReconstruction.jpg|Floor reconstruction showing a log floor covered in clay File:CucuteniClayStructureImprints.JPG|Archaeological Cucuteni–Trypillia building structure imprints in clay File:Cucutenibench.JPG|Vitrified clay bench </gallery>
==Bordei dwellings== {{See also|Bordei}} Some of the houses found by archeologists were [[Dugout (shelter)|dugout]] [[earth house]]s, of the style called ''bordei'' in both Romanian ({{lang-ro |italic=yes|bordei}}) and Ukrainian ({{lang-ua|italic=yes|бордей}}). Unlike surface dwellings characterized by walls with right angles and rectangular shapes the bordei houses were characterized by elliptical shapes. These houses would typically have a wooden [[floor]] that was about {{convert|1.5|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} below ground, which would place the roof at just above ground level.<ref name="Sorochin" /> Images of bordei homes may be seen at the Romanian Art Zone page<ref>{{Cite web|last=Grigorescu |first=Nicolae |title=Bordei in padure |trans-title=Bordei in the forest |publisher=Art Zone |date=1838–1907 |url=http://art-zone.ro/picturi/ng/2/Bordei_in_padure_nicolae_grigorescu.html |postscript=An online reproduction of an oil painting done by Romanian artist Nicolae Grigorescu (1838—1907) |accessdate=6 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201190925/http://art-zone.ro/picturi/ng/2/Bordei_in_padure_nicolae_grigorescu.html |archivedate=1 February 2009 }}</ref>
<gallery> File:CucuteniNeolithicChair.JPG|A clay model of a figurine in a chair File:CucuteniGoddessonthechair.JPG|A clay Precucuteni Goddess and chair File:CucuteniGoddesonthestoove.JPG|Clay models found at a Cucuteni-Trypillian site showing figurines sitting on a couch-like piece of furniture </gallery>
==House interior== [[File:Cucuteni House Clay Model.jpg|thumb|320px|left|Clay Model of house interior with two fireplaces]] Most of the Cucuteni-Trypillia houses were arranged by locating the front door opposite from where the [[fireplace]] sat. Large ceramic pottery containers used to store water and grain were placed next to the fireplace. Other ceramic containers, including the more valuable painted pottery, would also be located near the fireplace. Some of the fine painted pottery for which this culture is known would be used for clothing storage but most of it seems to have been used in rituals.<ref name="Monah">{{Citation |first=Dan |last=Monah |author-link=Dan Monah <!--http://www.arheo.ro/text/colectiv/Pagini_personale/Monah%20Dan.html--> |editor-last=Dumitroaia |editor-first=Gheorghe |contribution = Religie si arta in cultura Cucuteni (Religion and art in Cucuteni culture) |booktitle=Primul muzeu Cucuteni din Romania |title=Muzeul Cucuteni prima pentru Romania |trans-title=The first Cucuteni museum for Romania |series=Bibliotheca memoriae antiquitatis XV |year=2005 |pages=162–173 |place=Piatra-Neamț, Romania |publisher=Editura Foton |language=Romanian |oclc=319165024}}</ref>
The number of fireplaces found within each house varied from just one (which was the most common) to several, or even none. Each of the fireplaces found in houses that had more than one would have its own specific use such as one for cooking, one for [[Kiln|firing ceramics]], etc. Most Cucuteni-Trypillia fireplaces were a type of open [[fire pit]] and were usually constructed on the floor by laying down a bed of clay mixed with broken pottery shards and then covering this with a smooth clay-plastered surface.
It is assumed that furniture was extensively used however, due to the climate of this region, wood does not preserve well here. However some of the many miniature clay figurines found at Cucuteni-Trypillia sites were placed sitting or reclining on different pieces of furniture, some of which resemble sofas, chairs, or even ovens. There is also some evidence of furniture being incorporated into the structure of the walls of houses by using woven branches covered with clay.<ref name="Krichevski">{{Cite journal | last = Кричевский (Krichevski) | first = Евгений Юрьевич (Evgeniye Yurivich) | title = Трипольские площадки ; по раскопкам последних лет (Triploskiye ploshchadki : po raskopkam poslednič let) |trans-title=Trypillian ploshchadki : on the excavations of recent years | journal = Советская археология (''Sovyetskaya arkheologiya'' Soviet Archeology) | volume = 6 | publisher = институтом археологии АН СССР (Archeological Institute A.N. USSR) | location = Moscow | pages = 20–45 | language = Russian | issn = 0869-6063 | oclc = 26671888 | postscript = this journal later changed its title to Российская археология (Russian archeology)}}</ref>

'''Area studies''' (also '''regional studies''') are [[interdisciplinary]] fields of research and scholarship pertaining to particular [[geography|geographical]], [[nation]]al/[[Federal government|federal]], or [[culture|cultural]] regions. The term exists primarily as a general description for what are, in the practice of scholarship, many heterogeneous fields of research, encompassing both the [[social sciences]] and the [[humanities]]. Typical area study programs involve [[history]], [[political science]], [[sociology]], [[cultural studies]], [[languages]], [[geography]], [[literature]], and related disciplines. In contrast to cultural studies, area studies often include [[diaspora]] and [[emigration]] from the area.
==History== [[Interdisciplinary]] area studies became increasingly common in the [[United States of America]] and in Western scholarship after World War II. Before that war American universities had just a few faculty who taught or conducted research on the non-Western world. Foreign-area studies were virtually nonexistent. After the war, liberals and conservatives alike were concerned about the U.S. ability to respond effectively to perceived external threats from the [[Soviet Union]] and [[China]] in the context of the emerging [[Cold War]], as well as to the fall-out from the [[Decolonisation of Africa|Decolonization of Africa]] and [[decolonisation of Asia|Asia]].{{cn|date=August 2017}}
{{Double image|right|Diploma_de_Especialista_Universitario_de_la_Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid.jpg|200px|Diploma-licenciatura-estudos-europeus-universidade.jpg|200px|[[Latin American studies]] and [[European studies]] are examples of Area studies, offered both in [[Undergraduate education|undergraduate]] and [[Postgraduate education|graduate]] degrees, the images show examples from [[Complutense University of Madrid]] <ref>https://www.ucm.es/amelat/interes</ref> and [[Universidade Aberta|Aberta University]] <ref>https://www2.uab.pt/guiainformativo/eng_detailcursos.php?curso=14</ref>}}
In this context, the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], and the [[Carnegie Corporation of New York]] convened a series of meetings producing a broad consensus that to address this knowledge deficit, the U.S. must invest in international studies. Therefore, the foundations of the field are strongly rooted in America.{{cn|date=August 2017}} Participants argued that a large brain trust of internationally oriented [[political scientist]]s and [[economist]]s was an urgent national priority. There was a central tension, however, between those who felt strongly that, instead of applying Western models, social scientists should develop culturally and historically contextualized knowledge of various parts of the world by working closely with humanists, and those who thought social scientists should seek to develop overarching [[macrohistory | macrohistorial]] theories that could draw connections between patterns of change and development across different geographies. The former became area-studies advocates, the latter proponents of [[modernization theory]].
The [[Ford Foundation]] would eventually become the dominant player in shaping the area-studies program in the United States.<ref>Ellen Condliffe Lagemann, ''The Politics of Knowledge: The Carnegie Corporation, Philanthropy, and Public Policy'' (University of Chicago Press, 1992), p. 178.</ref>
In 1950 the foundation established the prestigious Foreign Area Fellowship Program (FAFP), the first large-scale national competition in support of area-studies training in the United States. From 1953 to 1966 it contributed $270 million to 34 universities for area and language studies. Also during this period, it poured millions of dollars into the committees run jointly by the [[Social Science Research Council]] and the [[American Council of Learned Societies]] for field-development workshops, conferences, and publication programs.<ref>David L. Szanton, "The Origin, Nature and Challenges of Area Studies in the United States," in ''The Politics of Knowledge: Area Studies and the Disciplines'', ed. David L. Szanton (University of California Press, 2004), pp. 10–11.</ref> Eventually, the SSRC-ACLS joint committees would take over the administration of FAFP.
Other large and important programs followed Ford's. Most notably, the [[National Defense Education Act]] of 1957, renamed the Higher Education Act in 1965, allocated funding for some 125 university-based area-studies units known as [[National Resource Center]] programs at U.S. universities, as well as for [[Foreign Language and Area Studies]] fellowships for graduate students.
Meanwhile, area studies were also developed in the Soviet Union.<ref> Note for example: {{cite book | last1 = Rupprecht | first1 = Tobias | author-link1 = | chapter = 5: Desk revolutionaries: Soviet Latin Americanists and internationalism in the late Soviet Union | title = Soviet Internationalism after Stalin | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OVoZCgAAQBAJ | location = Cambridge | publisher = Cambridge University Press | publication-date = 2015 | page = 273 | isbn = 9781107102880 | access-date = 2017-08-22 | quote = Academics from [[Moscow State University]] and [[Institute of World Economy and International Relations | IMEMO]] [founded in 1956] often turned to broader area studies at the ILA [the {{ill|Institute of Latin America|ru|Институт Латинской Америки РАН}} (founded in 1961 as part of the [[Soviet Academy of Sciences]])] and taught at [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations | MGIMO]] [founded in 1944], Moscow State University or [[Lumumba University]] [established in 1960]. Others moved from area studies into international journalism. [...] All state and Party organs that dealt with cultural diplomacy drew on the staff of area studies and their network of contacts. }} </ref>
==Controversy within the field== Since their inception, area studies have been subject to criticism—including by area specialists themselves. Many of them alleged that because area studies were connected to the Cold War agendas of the [[CIA]], the [[FBI]], and other intelligence and military agencies, participating in such programs was tantamount to serving as an agent of the state.<ref>See Bruce Cumings, "Boundary Displacement: Area Studies and International Studies during and after the Cold War," in ''Bulletin of Concerned Asian Scholars'' 29 (1997). http://www.mtholyoke.edu/acad/intrel/cumings2.htm. Retrieved 2009-04-23.</ref> Some argue that there is the notion that U.S concerns and research priorities will define the intellectual terrain of area studies.<ref>See Patrick O'Meara, "Changing perspectives on international education", (Indiana University Press 2010), pp. 81.</ref> Others insisted, however, that once they were established on university campuses, area studies began to encompass a much broader and deeper intellectual agenda than the one foreseen by government agencies, thus not American centric.<ref>Moseley, W.G. 2009. “Area Studies in a Global Context.” Chronicle of Higher Education. Nov 29. http://chronicle.com/article/Area-Studies-in-a-Global-Co/49284/</ref>
Arguably, one of the greatest threats to the area studies project was the rise of [[rational choice theory]] in political science and economics.<ref>See "Rational Choice Theory," by John Scott, in ''Understanding Contemporary Society: Theories of The Present'', edited by G. Browning, A. Halcli, and F. Webster (Sage Publications, 2000). {{cite web|url=http://privatewww.essex.ac.uk/~scottj/socscot7.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227085005/http://privatewww.essex.ac.uk/~scottj/socscot7.htm |archivedate=2009-02-27 |df= }}. Retrieved 2009-04-23.</ref> To mock one of the most outspoken rational choice theory critics, Japan scholar [[Chalmers Johnson]] asked: Why do you need to know Japanese or anything about Japan's history and culture if the methods of rational choice will explain why Japanese politicians and bureaucrats do the things they do?<ref>See Chalmers Johnson and E. B. Keehn, "A Disaster in the Making: Rational Choice and Asian Studies," ''The National Interest'' 36 (summer 1994), pp. 14–22.</ref>
Following the demise of the [[Soviet Union]], philanthropic foundations and scientific bureaucracies moved to attenuate their support for area studies, emphasizing instead interregional themes like "development and democracy". When the [[Social Science Research Council]] and the [[American Council of Learned Societies]], which had long served as the national [[wikt:nexus|nexus]] for raising and administering funds for area studies, underwent their first major restructuring in thirty years, closing down their area committees, scholars interpreted this as a massive signal about the changing research environment.<ref>See Cumings article, cited above.</ref>
==Fields==
Fields are defined differently from university to university, and from department to department, but common area-studies fields include:

studies]] (in the [[United States]] this has traditionally referred primarily to [[North America]] and especially the U.S.) *** [[American Studies in Britain]] *** [[African American studies]] *** *** [[Filipinology|Philippine studies]] *** [[Thai studies]] *** [[Vietnamese studies]] * [[European studies]] ** [[Austrian studies]] ** [[Baltic studies]] ** [[Basque studies]] ** [[Byzantine studies]] **[[Australian studies]] **[[New Zealand studies]] {{colend}}
Due to an increasing interest in studying translocal, transregional, transnational and transcontinental phenomena, a Potsdam-based research network has recently coined the term "TransArea Studies" [http://www.uni-potsdam.de/tapoints/ (POINTS – Potsdam International Network for TransArea Studies)].
Other interdisciplinary research fields such as [[women's studies]] (also known as [[gender studies]]), [[disability studies]], and [[ethnic studies]] (including [[African American studies]], [[Asian American studies]], [[Latino/a studies]], and [[Native American studies]]) are not part of '''area studies''' but are sometimes included in discussion along with it.
==Institutions==
Some entire institutions of higher education (tertiary education) are devoted solely to area studies such as [[School of Oriental and African Studies]], part of the [[University of London]], or the [[Tokyo University of Foreign Studies]] in Japan. At the [[University of Oxford]], the School of Interdisciplinary Area Studies (SIAS)[http://www.area-studies.ox.ac.uk/][http://www.area-studies.ox.ac.uk/ School of Interdiscplinary Area Studies, Oxford] and [[St Antony's College]] specialise in area studies, and hosts a number of post-graduate teaching programmes and research centres covering various regions of the world. [[Jawaharlal Nehru University]], New Delhi, is the only institution with immense contribution towards popularising area studies in India. An institution which exclusively deals with Area Studies is the [[German Institute of Global and Area Studies|GIGA]] (German Institute of Global Area Studies) in Germany. Additionally, [[Lund University]] in Sweden offers the largest [http://www.ace.lu.se/ Asian Studies] masters program in Northern Europe and is dedicated to promoting studies related to South Asia through its [http://www.sasnet.lu.se/ SASNet].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ace.lu.se/masters-programme/study-asia-in-lund|title=Study Asia in Lund!|author=|date=27 June 2017|website=lu.se|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>

page.title: Best management practice for water pollution

revision.text:
[[File:Trounce Pond.jpg|thumb|right|A [[retention pond]] for treatment of [[urban runoff]] (stormwater).]] '''Best management practices''' ('''BMPs''') is a term used in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] to describe a type of [[water pollution]] control. Historically the term has referred to auxiliary pollution controls in the fields of [[industrial wastewater treatment|industrial wastewater]] control and [[sewage treatment| municipal sewage]] control, while in [[stormwater]] management (both urban and rural) and [[wetland]] management, BMPs may refer to a principal control or treatment technique as well.
==Terminology== Beginning in the 20th century, designers of industrial and municipal sewage pollution controls typically utilized [[sewage treatment|engineered systems]] (e.g. [[Trickling filter|filters]], [[clarifier]]s, [[Bioreactor|biological reactors]]) to provide the central components of pollution control systems, and used the term "BMPs" to describe the supporting functions for these systems, such as operator training and equipment maintenance.
'''Stormwater management,''' as a specialized area within the field of [[environmental engineering]], emerged later in the 20th century, and some practitioners have used the term '''BMP''' to describe both structural or engineered control devices and systems (e.g. [[retention basin|retention ponds]]) to treat polluted stormwater, as well as operational or procedural practices (e.g. minimizing use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides). Other practitioners prefer to use the term '''Stormwater control measure''', due to the varied definitions of the term "BMP" and its use in non-stormwater practice.<ref>{{Cite book |author=National Research Council, Committee on Reducing Stormwater Discharge Contributions to Water Pollution |chapter-url=http://www.nap.edu/read/12465/chapter/7 |title=Urban Stormwater Management in the United States |chapter=5. Stormwater Management Approaches |date=2009 |publisher=National Academies Press |location=Washington, D.C. |isbn=978-0-309-12540-6}}</ref>
== U.S. Clean Water Act References to "BMP" == [[United States Congress|Congress]] referred to '''BMP''' in several sections of the U.S. [[Clean Water Act]] (CWA) but did not define the term. *The 1977 CWA used the term in describing the areawide waste treatment planning program<ref>United States. Clean Water Act of 1977, Pub.L. 95-217, December 27, 1977. Sections 208 (b), (i) and (j), {{USC|33|1288}}.</ref> and in procedures for controlling [[toxic]] [[water pollution|pollutants]] associated with industrial discharges.<ref>CWA sec. 304(e), {{USC|33|1314(e)}}.</ref> The [[Clean Water Act#Dredge and fill permits (wetlands)|"Section 404" program]], which covers dredge and fill permits, refers to BMPs in one of the enforcement exemptions.<ref>CWA sec. 404(f), {{USC|33|1344}}.</ref> *References to stormwater BMPs first appear in the 1987 amendment to the CWA in describing the Nonpoint Source Management Demonstration Program.<ref>Water Quality Act of 1987, Pub.L. 100-4, February 4, 1987. CWA sec. 319(a),(b),(h),(l), & (m), {{USC|33|1329}}.</ref> *Another stormwater BMP reference was added in 2001 with the authorization for a Wet Weather Watershed Pilot Project program.<ref>Wet Weather Water Quality Act of 2000, December 21, 2000. Added by the Miscellaneous Appropriations Act, 2001 (114 Stat. 2763A–225), as enacted into law by section 1(a)(6) of Pub.L. 106–554 (114 Stat. 2763). Amended CWA sec.121(a)(2), {{USC|33|1274}}.</ref>
== EPA definitions == In implementing the CWA, the U.S. [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) defined '''BMP''' in the federal wastewater permit regulations, initially to refer to auxiliary procedures for industrial wastewater controls. :...schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the pollution of waters of the United States, BMPs also include treatment requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control plant site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw material storage.<ref>U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Washington, D.C. "EPA Administered Permit Programs: The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System." ''Code of Federal Regulations,'' {{CodeFedReg|40|122|2}}.</ref>
Later the Agency added a reference to stormwater management BMPs. :...each NPDES permit shall include conditions meeting the following requirements when applicable... (k) Best management practices (BMPs) to control or abate the discharge of pollutants when: ... (2) Authorized under section 402(p) of the CWA for the control of storm water discharges...<ref>EPA. {{CodeFedReg|40|122|44}}.</ref>
== Industrial wastewater BMPs == Industrial wastewater BMPs are considered an adjunct to engineered [[sewage treatment|treatment]] systems. Typical BMPs include operator training, maintenance practices, and spill control procedures for treatment chemicals.<ref>For example: {{cite report |date=July 1994 |title=Best Management Practices and Spill Response: Guidance Document |url=https://open.alberta.ca/dataset/f7457ac3-7967-49c9-94dd-7986cb6624da/resource/6b40c069-d846-4fa2-a98b-bfd060a7ab3a/download/best-management-practices-spill-response-guidance-document.pdf |publisher=Alberta Environmental Protection |location=Edmonton, AB}}</ref> There are also many BMPs available which are specific to particular industrial processes, for example: * source reduction practices in metal finishing industries (e.g. substituting less toxic [[solvent]]s or using water-based cleaners); * in the [[chemical industry]], capturing equipment washdown waters for recycle/reuse at various process stages; * in the [[paper industry]], using [[process control]] monitoring to optimize [[bleaching]] processes, and reduce the overall amount of bleach used.<ref>{{cite report |date=October 1993 |title=Guidance Manual for Developing Best Management Practices (BMP) |chapter=Ch. 3. Industry-Specific Best Management Practices |url=https://www3.epa.gov/npdes/pubs/owm0274.pdf |publisher=EPA |id=EPA-833-B-93-004}}</ref>
== Stormwater management BMPs == [[Stormwater]] management BMPs are control measures taken to mitigate changes to both quantity and quality of [[urban runoff]] caused through changes to [[land use]]. Generally BMPs focus on [[water quality]] problems caused by increased [[impervious surface]]s from [[land development]].<ref>{{Cite book |author=National Research Council, Committee on Reducing Stormwater Discharge Contributions to Water Pollution |chapter-url=https://www.nap.edu/read/12465/chapter/5 |title=Urban Stormwater Management in the United States |chapter=3. Hydrologic, Geomorphic, and Biological Effects of Urbanization on Watersheds |date=2009 |publisher=National Academies Press |location=Washington, D.C. |isbn=978-0-309-12540-6}}</ref> BMPs are designed to reduce stormwater volume, peak flows, and/or [[nonpoint source pollution]] through [[evapotranspiration]], [[Infiltration (hydrology)|infiltration]], [[detention basin|detention]], and filtration or biological and chemical actions.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Debo |first1=Thomas N. |last2=Reese |first2=Andrew J. |authorlink= |title=Municipal Stormwater Management |url= |accessdate= |year=2003 |edition=2nd |publisher=CRC Press |location=Boca Raton, FL |isbn=1-56670-584-3 |pages=}}</ref> BMPs also can improve receiving-water quality by extending the duration of outflows in comparison to inflow duration (known as hydrograph extension), which dilutes the stormwater discharged into a larger volume of upstream flow.<ref>{{cite report |author-last1=Granato |author-first1=G.E. |date=2014 |title=Statistics for stochastic modeling of volume reduction, hydrograph extension, and water-quality treatment by structural stormwater runoff best management practices (BMPs) |url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2014/5037/ |publisher=U.S. Geological Survey |id=Scientific Investigations Report 2014–5037}}</ref>
Stormwater BMPs can be classified as "structural" (i.e., devices installed or constructed on a site) or "non-structural" (procedures, such as modified landscaping practices or street sweeping). There are a variety of BMPs available; selection typically depends on site characteristics and pollutant removal objectives. EPA has published a series of stormwater BMP fact sheets for use by local governments, builders and property owners.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/npdes/national-menu-best-management-practices-bmps-stormwater |title=National Menu of Best Management Practices (BMPs) for Stormwater |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2016 |website=National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System |publisher=EPA}}</ref>
Stormwater management BMPs can be also categorized into four basic types: # Storage practices: ponds; recovery; [[Green infrastructure|green infrastructure design]]. # Vegetative practices: [[Buffer zone|buffers]]; channels; [[green roof]]s; wetlands; functional art;{{explain|date=November 2018}} stormwater wetland park design; wetland park engineering & design. # Filtration/Infiltration practices: filtering; [[Infiltration (hydrology)|infiltration]]; [[Rain garden|rain gardens]]; [[Permeable paving|porous pavement]]; civic infrastructure and design; functional stormwater design. # Water sensitive development: better site design;{{explain|date=November 2018}} open space site design; [[Low-impact development (U.S. and Canada)|low impact development]].
== See also == *[[Industrial wastewater treatment]] *[[Low-impact development (Canada/US)|Low Impact Development]] (LID) *[[Nationwide Urban Runoff Program]] (NURP) - EPA research program on stormwater BMPs *[[Stochastic Empirical Loading and Dilution Model]] for modeling the performance of BMPs *[[Sustainable urban drainage systems]]

{{Infobox_gene}} '''Calponin 1''' is a basic smooth muscle [[protein]] that in [[human]]s is encoded by the ''CNN1'' [[gene]].<ref name="entrez">{{cite web | title = Entrez Gene: calponin 1, basic, smooth muscle | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=gene&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=1264| accessdate = }}</ref>
The ''CNN1'' gene is located at 19p13.2-p13.1 in the human chromosomal [[genome]] and contains 7 [[exons]], encoding the protein calponin 1, an [[actin]] filament-associated regulatory protein.<ref name="Takahashi_1994">{{cite journal | vauthors = Takahashi K, Abe M, Hiwada K, Kokubu T | title = A novel troponin T-like protein (calponin) in vascular smooth muscle: interaction with tropomyosin paracrystals | journal = Journal of Hypertension Supplement | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = S40-3 | date = December 1988 | pmid = 3241227 | doi=10.1097/00004872-198812040-00008}}</ref> Human calponin 1 is a 33.2-KDa protein consists of 297 [[amino acid]]s with an [[isoelectric point]] of 9.1,<ref name = "Gao_1996">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gao J, Hwang JM, Jin JP | title = Complete nucleotide sequence, structural organization, and an alternatively spliced exon of mouse h1-calponin gene | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 218 | issue = 1 | pages = 292–7 | date = January 1996 | pmid = 8573148 | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.1996.0051 }}</ref> thus calponin 1 is also known as basic calponin.
==Evolution== [[File:CNN1 wikipage.jpg|thumb|'''Figure 1''': Evolutionary lineage of vertebrate ''CNN1''.|400x400px]] Three homologous genes, ''Cnn1'', ''Cnn2'' and ''Cnn3'', have evolved in [[vertebrate]]s, encoding three [[Protein isoform|isoforms]] of [[calponin]]: calponin 1,<ref name = "Gao_1996" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Strasser P, Gimona M, Moessler H, Herzog M, Small JV | title = Mammalian calponin. Identification and expression of genetic variants | journal = FEBS Letters | volume = 330 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–8 | date = September 1993 | pmid = 8370452 | doi=10.1016/0014-5793(93)80909-e}}</ref> [[calponin 2]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Masuda H, Tanaka K, Takagi M, Ohgami K, Sakamaki T, Shibata N, Takahashi K | title = Molecular cloning and characterization of human non-smooth muscle calponin | journal = Journal of Biochemistry | volume = 120 | issue = 2 | pages = 415–24 | date = August 1996 | pmid = 8889829 | doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.jbchem.a021428}}</ref> [[Calponin 3, acidic|calponin 3]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Applegate D, Feng W, Green RS, Taubman MB | title = Cloning and expression of a novel acidic calponin isoform from rat aortic vascular smooth muscle | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 269 | issue = 14 | pages = 10683–90 | date = April 1994 | pmid = 8144658 }}</ref> respectively. Protein [[sequence alignment]] shows that calponin 1 is highly conserved in [[mammal]]s but more diverged among lower vertebrates.
==Smooth muscle-specific expression== The [[Gene expression|expression]] of CNN1 is specific to differentiated mature smooth muscle cells, suggesting a role in [[Muscle contraction|contractile functions]]. Calponin 1 is up-regulated in [[smooth muscle tissue]]s during postnatal development<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hossain MM, Hwang DY, Huang QQ, Sasaki Y, Jin JP | title = Developmentally regulated expression of calponin isoforms and the effect of h2-calponin on cell proliferation | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Cell Physiology | volume = 284 | issue = 1 | pages = C156-67 | date = January 2003 | pmid = 12388067 | doi = 10.1152/ajpcell.00233.2002 }}</ref> with a higher content in phasic smooth muscle of the [[Gastrointestinal tract|digestive tract]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jin JP, Walsh MP, Resek ME, McMartin GA | title = Expression and epitopic conservation of calponin in different smooth muscles and during development | journal = Biochemistry and Cell Biology | volume = 74 | issue = 2 | pages = 187–96 | pmid = 9213427 | doi=10.1139/o96-019 | year=1996}}</ref>
==Structure-function relationship== [[File:Calponin structure wikigene final.jpg|thumb|534x534px|'''Figure 2. Structural and functional domains of calponin.''' The linear structural map summarized primarily from studies of chicken calponin 1 illustrates the structural and functional domains of calponin. The CH domain, two actin-binding sites, three repeating sequence motifs, and the C-terminal variable region are outlined. The CH domain overlaps with the ERK signaling binding region. Amino acid sequences of the two actin-binding sites in the three isoforms and the three repeating motifs of calponin 1 are shown in the insets. The regulatory phosphorylation sites Ser<sub>175</sub> and Thr<sub>184</sub> are located in the second actin-binding site that overlaps with the first repeating motif. Potentially phosphorylatable serine residues corresponding to Ser<sub>175</sub> are conserved in repeats 2 and 3, while a Thr<sub>184</sub> equivalent is conserved in repeat 2. Different from calponin 1 and calponin 3, calponin 2 has a potentially phosphorylatable additional serine at position 177. ]] The majority of structure-function relationship studies of calponin were with experiments using chicken calponin 1. Primary structure of calponin consists of a conserved [[N-terminus|N-terminal]] [[Calponin homology domain|calponin homology (CH) domain]], a conserved middle region containing two actin-binding sites, and a [[C-terminus|C-terminal]] variable region that contributes to the differences among there isoforms.
===The CH domain=== The CH domain was found in a number of actin-binding proteins (such as [[Actinin alpha 1|α-actinin]], [[spectrin]], and [[filamin]]) to form the actin-binding region or serve as a regulatory structure.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gimona M, Djinovic-Carugo K, Kranewitter WJ, Winder SJ | title = Functional plasticity of CH domains | journal = FEBS Letters | volume = 513 | issue = 1 | pages = 98–106 | date = February 2002 | pmid = 11911887 | doi=10.1016/s0014-5793(01)03240-9}}</ref> However, the CH domain in calponin is not the binding site for actin nor does it regulate the modes of calponin-F-actin binding.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Galkin VE, Orlova A, Fattoum A, Walsh MP, Egelman EH | title = The CH-domain of calponin does not determine the modes of calponin binding to F-actin | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | volume = 359 | issue = 2 | pages = 478–85 | date = June 2006 | pmid = 16626733 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmb.2006.03.044 }}</ref> Nonetheless, CH domain in calponin was found to bind to extra-cellular regulated [[kinase]] (ERK) for calponin to play a possible role as an [[Signal transducing adaptor protein|adaptor protein]] in the ERK signaling cascades.<ref name="Leinweber_1999">{{cite journal | vauthors = Leinweber BD, Leavis PC, Grabarek Z, Wang CL, Morgan KG | title = Extracellular regulated kinase (ERK) interaction with actin and the calponin homology (CH) domain of actin-binding proteins | journal = The Biochemical Journal | volume = 344 | pages = 117–23 | date = November 1999 | pmid = 10548541 | doi=10.1042/0264-6021:3440117 | issue=1 | pmc=1220621}}</ref>
===Actin-binding sites=== Calponin binds actin to promote and sustain [[polymerization]]. The binding of calponin to F-actin inhibits the [[Magnesium-ATPase|MgATPase]] activity of smooth muscle [[myosin]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | vauthors = Abe M, Takahashi K, Hiwada K | title = Effect of calponin on actin-activated myosin ATPase activity | journal = Journal of Biochemistry | volume = 108 | issue = 5 | pages = 835–8 | date = November 1990 | pmid = 2150518 | doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.jbchem.a123289}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mezgueldi M, Fattoum A, Derancourt J, Kassab R | title = Mapping of the functional domains in the amino-terminal region of calponin | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 267 | issue = 22 | pages = 15943–51 | date = August 1992 | pmid = 1639822 }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="Winder_1993">{{cite journal | vauthors = Winder SJ, Walsh MP | title = Calponin: thin filament-linked regulation of smooth muscle contraction | journal = Cellular Signalling | volume = 5 | issue = 6 | pages = 677–86 | date = November 1993 | pmid = 8130072 | doi=10.1016/0898-6568(93)90029-l}}</ref> Calponin binds F-actin through two sites at residues 144-162 and 171-188 in chicken calponin 1. The two actin-binding sites are conserved in the three calponin isoforms.
There are three repeating [[sequence motif]]s in calponin next to the C-terminal region. This repeating structure is conserved in all three isoforms and across [[species]]. Outlined in Fig. 2, the first repeating motif overlaps with the second actin-binding site and contains [[protein kinase C]] (PKC) [[phosphorylation]] sites Ser175 and Thr184 that are not present in the first actin-binding site. This feature is consistent with the hypothesis that the second actin-binding site plays a regulatory role in the binding of calponin to the [[Microfilament|actin filament]]. Similar sequences as well as potential phosphorylation sites are present in repeats 2 and 3 whereas their function is unknown.
===C-terminal variable region=== The C-terminal segment of calponin has diverged significantly among the three isoforms. The variable lengths and amino acid sequences of the C-terminal segment produce the size and charge differences among the calponin isoforms. The corresponding charge features rendered calponin 1, 2 and 3 the names of basic, neutral and acidic calponins.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jin JP, Zhang Z, Bautista JA | title = Isoform diversity, regulation, and functional adaptation of troponin and calponin | journal = Critical Reviews in Eukaryotic Gene Expression | volume = 18 | issue = 2 | pages = 93–124 | pmid = 18304026 | doi=10.1615/critreveukargeneexpr.v18.i2.10 | year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wu KC, Jin JP | title = Calponin in non-muscle cells | journal = [[Cell Biochemistry and Biophysics]] | volume = 52 | issue = 3 | pages = 139–48 | pmid = 18946636 | doi = 10.1007/s12013-008-9031-6 | year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu R, Jin JP | date = 2015 | title = Calponin: A mechanical tension-modulated regulator of cytoskeleton and cell motility. | journal = Current Topics in Biochemical Research | volume = 16 | pages = 1–15 }}</ref>
The C-terminal segment of calponin has an effect on weakening the binding of calponin to F-actin. [[Deletion (genetics)|Deletion]] of the C-terminal tail strongly enhanced the actin-binding and bundling activities of all three isoforms of calponin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bartegi A, Roustan C, Kassab R, Fattoum A | title = Fluorescence studies of the carboxyl-terminal domain of smooth muscle calponin effects of F-actin and salts | journal = European Journal of Biochemistry | volume = 262 | issue = 2 | pages = 335–41 | date = June 1999 | pmid = 10336616 | doi=10.1046/j.1432-1327.1999.00390.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Danninger C, Gimona M | title = Live dynamics of GFP-calponin: isoform-specific modulation of the actin cytoskeleton and autoregulation by C-terminal sequences | journal = Journal of Cell Science | volume = 113 | pages = 3725–36 | date = November 2000 | pmid = 11034901 | issue=21}}</ref> The C-terminal tail regulates the interaction with F-actin by altering the function of the second actin-bing site of calponin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Burgstaller G, Kranewitter WJ, Gimona M | title = The molecular basis for the autoregulation of calponin by isoform-specific C-terminal tail sequences | journal = Journal of Cell Science | volume = 115 | issue = Pt 10 | pages = 2021–9 | date = May 2002 | pmid = 11973344 }}</ref>
==Regulation of smooth muscle contractility==
Numerous [[in vitro]] experimental data indicate that calponin 1 functions as an inhibitory regulator of smooth muscle contractility through inhibiting [[Myofibril|actomyosin]] interactions.<ref name="Takahashi_1994"/><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Takahashi K, Hiwada K, Kokubu T | title = Isolation and characterization of a 34,000-dalton calmodulin- and F-actin-binding protein from chicken gizzard smooth muscle | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 141 | issue = 1 | pages = 20–6 | date = November 1986 | pmid = 3606745 | doi=10.1016/s0006-291x(86)80328-x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Allen BG, Walsh MP | title = The biochemical basis of the regulation of smooth-muscle contraction | journal = Trends in Biochemical Sciences | volume = 19 | issue = 9 | pages = 362–8 | date = September 1994 | pmid = 7985229 | doi=10.1016/0968-0004(94)90112-0}}</ref> In this regulation, binding of Ca<sup>2+</sup>-calmodulin and PKC phosphorylation dissociate calponin 1 from the actin filament and facilitate smooth muscle contraction.<ref name="Naka_1990">{{cite journal | vauthors = Naka M, Kureishi Y, Muroga Y, Takahashi K, Ito M, Tanaka T | title = Modulation of smooth muscle calponin by protein kinase C and calmodulin | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 171 | issue = 3 | pages = 933–7 | date = September 1990 | pmid = 2222454 | doi=10.1016/0006-291x(90)90773-g}}</ref>
[[In vivo]] data also support the role of calponin 1 as regulator of smooth muscle contractility. While [[Aorta|aortic]] smooth muscle of adult Wistar Kyoto [[rat]]s, which naturally lacks calponin 1, is fully contractile, it has a decreased sensitivity to [[norepinephrine]] activation.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Nigam R, Triggle CR, Jin JP | title = h1- and h2-calponins are not essential for norepinephrine- or sodium fluoride-induced contraction of rat aortic smooth muscle | journal = Journal of Muscle Research and Cell Motility | volume = 19 | issue = 6 | pages = 695–703 | date = August 1998 | pmid = 9742453 | doi=10.1023/a:1005389300151}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Facemire C, Brozovich FV, Jin JP | title = The maximal velocity of vascular smooth muscle shortening is independent of the expression of calponin | journal = Journal of Muscle Research and Cell Motility | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 367–73 | date = May 2000 | pmid = 11032347 | doi=10.1023/a:1005680614296}}</ref> [[Gelatinase A|Matrix metalloproteinase-2]] [[proteolysis]] of calponin 1 resulted in [[Blood vessel|vascular]] hypocontractility to [[phenylephrine]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Castro MM, Cena J, Cho WJ, Walsh MP, Schulz R | title = Matrix metalloproteinase-2 proteolysis of calponin-1 contributes to vascular hypocontractility in endotoxemic rats | journal = Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology | volume = 32 | issue = 3 | pages = 662–8 | date = March 2012 | pmid = 22199370 | doi = 10.1161/ATVBAHA.111.242685 }}</ref> [[Vas deferens]] smooth muscle from calponin 1 [[Knockout mouse|knockout mice]] showed faster maximum shortening velocity.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Takahashi K, Yoshimoto R, Fuchibe K, Fujishige A, Mitsui-Saito M, Hori M, Ozaki H, Yamamura H, Awata N, Taniguchi S, Katsuki M, Tsuchiya T, Karaki H | title = Regulation of shortening velocity by calponin in intact contracting smooth muscles | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 279 | issue = 1 | pages = 150–7 | date = December 2000 | pmid = 11112431 | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.2000.3909 }}</ref> Calponin 1 knockout mice exhibited blunted [[Microtubule-associated protein|MAP]] response to phenylephrine administration.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Masuki S, Takeoka M, Taniguchi S, Nose H | title = Enhanced baroreflex sensitivity in free-moving calponin knockout mice | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Heart and Circulatory Physiology | volume = 284 | issue = 3 | pages = H939-46 | date = March 2003 | pmid = 12433658 | doi = 10.1152/ajpheart.00610.2002 }}</ref>
==Phosphorylation regulation== There is a large collection of in vitro evidences demonstrating the phosphorylation regulation of calponin. The primary phosphorylation sites are Ser175 and Thr184 in the second actin-binding site (Fig. 2). Experimental data showed that Ser175 and Thr184 in calponin 1 are phosphorylated by PKC in vitro.<ref name="Naka_1990"/> Direct association was found between calponin 1 and [[PKC alpha|PKCα]]<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Somara S, Bitar KN | title = Direct association of calponin with specific domains of PKC-alpha | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Gastrointestinal and Liver Physiology | volume = 295 | issue = 6 | pages = G1246-54 | date = December 2008 | pmid = 18948438 | doi = 10.1152/ajpgi.90461.2008 | pmc=2604804}}</ref> and [[PRKCE|PKCε]].<ref name="Leinweber_1999"/> [[CAMK|Calmodulin-dependent kinase II]] and [[Rho-associated protein kinase|Rho-kinase]] are also found to phosphorylate calponin at Ser175 and Thr184 in vitro.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Walsh MP | title = The Ayerst Award Lecture 1990. Calcium-dependent mechanisms of regulation of smooth muscle contraction | journal = Biochemistry and Cell Biology | volume = 69 | issue = 12 | pages = 771–800 | date = December 1991 | pmid = 1818584 | doi=10.1139/o91-119}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kaneko T, Amano M, Maeda A, Goto H, Takahashi K, Ito M, Kaibuchi K | title = Identification of calponin as a novel substrate of Rho-kinase | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 273 | issue = 1 | pages = 110–6 | date = June 2000 | pmid = 10873572 | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.2000.2901 }}</ref> Of these two residues, the main site of regulatory phosphorylation by calmodulin-dependent kinase II and Rho-kinase is Ser175. Dephosphorylation of calponin is [[Catalysis|catalyzed]] by type 2B protein [[phosphatase]]<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Fraser ED, Walsh MP | title = Dephosphorylation of calponin by type 2B protein phosphatase | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 34 | issue = 28 | pages = 9151–8 | date = July 1995 | pmid = 7619814 | doi=10.1021/bi00028a026}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ichikawa K, Ito M, Okubo S, Konishi T, Nakano T, Mino T, Nakamura F, Naka M, Tanaka T | title = Calponin phosphatase from smooth muscle: a possible role of type 1 protein phosphatase in smooth muscle relaxation | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 193 | issue = 3 | pages = 827–33 | date = June 1993 | pmid = 8391807 | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.1993.1700 }}</ref>
Unphosphorylated calponin binds to actin and inhibits actomyosin MgATPase. Ser175 phosphorylation alters the [[Chemical structure|molecular conformation]] of calponin and [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociates]] calponin from F-actin.<ref name="Jin_2000">{{cite journal | vauthors = Jin JP, Walsh MP, Sutherland C, Chen W | title = A role for serine-175 in modulating the molecular conformation of calponin | journal = The Biochemical Journal | volume = 350 | pages = 579–88 | date = September 2000 | pmid = 10947974 | doi=10.1042/0264-6021:3500579 | issue=2 | pmc=1221287}}</ref> The consequence is to release the inhibition of actomyosin MgATPase and increase the production of force.<ref name="Winder_1993"/><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tang DC, Kang HM, Jin JP, Fraser ED, Walsh MP | title = Structure-function relations of smooth muscle calponin. The critical role of serine 175 | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 271 | issue = 15 | pages = 8605–11 | date = April 1996 | pmid = 8621490 | doi=10.1074/jbc.271.15.8605}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gerthoffer WT, Pohl J | title = Caldesmon and calponin phosphorylation in regulation of smooth muscle contraction | journal = Canadian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacology | volume = 72 | issue = 11 | pages = 1410–4 | date = November 1994 | pmid = 7767886 | doi=10.1139/y94-203}}</ref>
Despite the overwhelming evidence for the phosphorylation regulation of calponin obtained from in vitro studies, phosphorylated calponin is not readily detectable in vivo or in living cells under physiological conditions.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bárány M, Bárány K | title = Calponin phosphorylation does not accompany contraction of various smooth muscles | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1179 | issue = 2 | pages = 229–33 | date = November 1993 | pmid = 8218366 | doi=10.1016/0167-4889(93)90146-g}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gimona M, Sparrow MP, Strasser P, Herzog M, Small JV | title = Calponin and SM 22 isoforms in avian and mammalian smooth muscle. Absence of phosphorylation in vivo | journal = European Journal of Biochemistry | volume = 205 | issue = 3 | pages = 1067–75 | date = May 1992 | pmid = 1576991 | doi=10.1111/j.1432-1033.1992.tb16875.x}}</ref> Based on the observation that PKC phosphorylation of calponin 1 weakens the [[Ligand (biochemistry)|binding affinity]] for the actin filaments,<ref name="Jin_2000"/> the phosphorylated calponin may not be stable in the actin cytoskeleton thus be degraded in the cell.
==Notes== {{Academic-written review | wikidate = 2016 | journal = [[Gene (journal)|Gene]] | title = {{#property:P1476|from=Q37666020}} | authors = {{#property:P2093|from=Q37666020}} | date = {{#property:P577|from=Q37666020}} | volume = {{#property:P478|from=Q37666020}} | issue = {{#property:P433|from=Q37666020}} | pages = {{#property:P304|from=Q37666020}} | doi = {{#property:P356|from=Q37666020}} | pmid = {{#property:P698|from=Q37666020}} | pmc = {{#property:P932|from=Q37666020}} }}

'''Diploma in Computer Science''', originally known as the "Diploma in Numerical Analysis and Automatic Computing", was a conversion course in [[Computer Science]] offered by the [[University of Cambridge]], [[England]]. It was equivalent to a [[master's degree]] in present-day nomenclature but the title ''diploma'' was retained for historic reasons, "diploma" being the archaic term for a master's degree.
The Diploma was the world's first full-year taught course in computer science, starting in 1953. It attracted students with degrees in mathematics, science and engineering. At its peak, there were 50 students on the course. UK government ([[EPSRC]]) funding was withdrawn in 2001 and student numbers dropped dramatically. In 2007, the University took the decision to withdraw the Diploma at the end of the 2007-08 academical year, after 55 years of service.
==History== The introduction of this one-year graduate course was motivated by a [[University of Cambridge]] Mathematics Faculty Board Report on the "demand for postgraduate instruction in numerical analysis and automatic computing … <nowiki>[which]</nowiki> if not met, there is a danger that the application to scientific research of the machines now being built will be hampered". The [[University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory]] "was one of the pioneers in the de and use of electronic computing-machines (sic)". It had introduced a Summer School in 1950, but the Report noted that "The Summer School deals <nowiki>[only]</nowiki> with 'programming', rather than the general theory of the numerical methods which are programmed." The Diploma "would include theoretical and practical work … <nowiki>[and also]</nowiki> instruction about the various types of computing-machine … and the principles of design on which they are based." With only a few students initially, no extra staff would be needed.<ref>[http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/UoCCL/misc/EDSAC99/history.html Informal history of the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory]</ref>
University-supported teaching and research staff in the [[University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory|Laboratory]] at the time were [[Maurice Wilkes]] (head of the laboratory), [[J. C. P. Miller]], W. Renwick, E. N. Mutch, and S. Gill, joined slightly later by C. B. Haselgrove.
In its final incarnation, the Diploma was a 10-month course, evaluated two-thirds on examination and one-third on a project dissertation. Most of the examined courses were shared by the second year ("Part IB") of the undergraduate [[Computer Science Tripos]] course, with some additional lectures specifically for the Diploma students and four of the third year undergraduate ("Part II") lecture courses also included.
There were three grades of result from the Diploma: distinction (roughly equivalent to first class honours), pass (equivalent to second or third class honours), and fail.
==Notable alumni== {{div col|colwidth=35em}} * [[Ann Copestake]] * [[Samson Abramsky]] * [[Ian Bell (programmer)|Ian Bell]] * [[Christoph Schmidt (German-Italian relations expert)]] * [[Stephen R. Bourne|Steve Bourne]] * [[Ben Nicholson (Renown VBA Expert)]] * [[Matthew Fisher (computer scientist)|Matthew Fisher]] * [[Simon Peyton Jones]] * [[Stan Kelly-Bootle]] * [[Mark Harthan (Scrum Master)]] * [[Lee Hsien Loong]] * [[Martin Richards (computer scientist)|Martin Richards]] * [[Bill Thompson (technology writer)]] * [[Eben Upton]] * [[Thomas Jenner (Healthcare IT Innovator)]] {{div col end}}
